Starlight

Starlight

The idea

The base idea from starlight was to use very simple math functions such as sine and cosine and try to build complex and beautiful shapes from them. I used the Processing programming environment to build the algorithm used to generates the shapes.

Learning to code

Before this project, I was fascinated by generative design and interactive installations, but I had no clue how they were made. Knowing that at my school I will attend the generative art class I decided to experiment a bit by myself



float cpt;
float inc = 0.07;

void setup(){
  fullScreen();
  background(0);
  stroke(255);
  strokeWeight(1);
  init();
}


void init(){
    cpt = 1;
}


void draw(){
    translate(width/2,height/2);
    
    point(cpt*60,sin(cpt)*cpt*10);
    point(cpt*60,sin(-cpt)*cpt*10);
    
    
    cpt += inc; 
}

Of course, the complexity of the code grew really fast as my knowledge of object-oriented programming was really poor. Instead of making functions as I would do now I was a copy-pasting complete block of code. That resulted in many problems but those attempts ended up generating visuals I had never expected neither intended to make.

The result

The use of square and logarithm functions helped me to handle the growing complexity fo the shape by making them collapse or explode at certain ranges. The first shapes looked more like math book illustrations than generative art. But by adding symmetries and rotations and experimenting a lot I finally obtained some interesting visuals.

Parametric

By making the code parametric I ended up being able to generate a large amount of star-like patterns. Over time I added more and more variables to fine-tune the look of each artwork.

I tried to render it on a larger canvas to get more details and I was surprised by the complexity of the shapes I was able to build in under 100 lines of code.

What I learned

Even it was a very small project I learned a lot of things while building it. It was my first step in the programming world and it allowed me to understand that programming was not about knowing a language but about learning how to solve problems one step after another.

You can find more visuals about this project on Behance.

This project also made me understand how valuable it is to know how to code. Because in less than 3 days I was able to generate thousands of visuals. Without that knowledge, It would have taken weeks to complete. Learning how to automate my tedious tasks helped me to become more efficient and focus more on what really brings value in my work.

PS: the code will soon be available on my GitHub.
